title: 1684-F
statement: F. Diverse Segmentstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given an array $$$a$$$ of $$$n$$$ integers. Also you are given $$$m$$$ subsegments of that array. The left and the right endpoints of the $$$j$$$-th segment are $$$l_j$$$ and $$$r_j$$$ respectively.You are allowed to makeno more than oneoperation. In that operation you choose any subsegment of the array $$$a$$$ and replace each value on this segment with any integer (you are also allowed to keep elements the same).You have to apply this operation so that for the given $$$m$$$ segments, the elements on each segment are distinct. More formally, for each $$$1 \\le j \\le m$$$ all elements $$$a_{l_{j}}, a_{l_{j}+1}, \\ldots, a_{r_{j}-1}, a_{r_{j}}$$$ should be distinct.You don't want to use the operation on a big segment, so you have to find the smallest length of a segment, so that you can apply the operation to this segment and meet the above-mentioned conditions. If it is not needed to use this operation, the answer is $$$0$$$.InputThe input consists of multiple test cases. The first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 100$$$) — the number of test cases. Description of the test cases follows.The first line of each test case contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$m$$$ ($$$1 \\le n, m \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$) — the size of the array and the number of segments respectively.The next line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\ldots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le a_i \\le 10^9$$$) — the elements of $$$a$$$.Each of the next $$$m$$$ lines contains two integers $$$l_j$$$, $$$r_j$$$ ($$$1 \\le l_j \\le r_j \\le n$$$) — the left and the right endpoints of the $$$j$$$-th segment.It's guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ and the sum of $$$m$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$2 \\cdot 10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case output a single integer — the smallest length of a segment you can apply an operation on making the elements on all given segments distinct. If it is not needed to use the operation, output $$$0$$$.ExampleInput57 31 1 2 1 3 3 51 44 52 45 210 1 6 14 14 52 44 55 7 5 62 21 32 43 33 47 32 2 2 7 8 2 24 44 45 51 11231 1Output2 0 1 0 0NoteIn the first test case you can perform the operation on the segment $$$[1, 2]$$$ and make $$$a = [5, 6, 2, 1, 3, 3, 5]$$$. Then the elements on each segment are distinct.On the segment $$$[1, 4]$$$ there are $$$[5, 6, 2, 1]$$$.On the segment $$$[4, 5]$$$ there are $$$[1, 3]$$$.On the segment $$$[2, 4]$$$ there are $$$[6, 2, 1, 3]$$$.This way on each of the given segments all elements are distinct. Also, it is impossible to change any single integer to make elements distinct on each segment. That is why the answer is $$$2$$$.In the second test case the elements on each segment are already distinct, so we should not perform the operation.In the third test case we can replace the first $$$5$$$ by $$$1$$$. This way we will get $$$[1, 7, 5, 6]$$$ where all elements are distinct so on each given segment all elements are distinct.

processed.result:
You are given an array of $n$ integers. You are also given $m$ subsegments of this array.  

For each subsegment, you are allowed to replace all the integers within that subsegment with any other integers (you can also keep the original integers).

Your goal is to find the smallest possible length of a subsegment that you need to replace so that all the integers within each of the $m$ subsegments are distinct. If you don't need to replace any subsegment, the answer is 0. 


**Input:**

* The first line contains the number of test cases, $t$.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains two integers, $n$ (the size of the array) and $m$ (the number of subsegments).
    * The next line contains $n$ integers, representing the elements of the array.
    * Each of the next $m$ lines contains two integers, $l_j$ and $r_j$, representing the left and right endpoints of the $j$-th subsegment.

**Output:**

For each test case, output a single integer representing the smallest length of a subsegment you need to replace.

You are given a list of numbers and several ranges within that list.  You can change all the numbers in a single range to any values you want.  Find the smallest range you need to change so that all the ranges have unique numbers within them. If no changes are needed, the answer is 0.
